description:
In the cluster eff of Vietnamese joints and feces on the streets, this place is a real gem in the TL.

I always get the Bo Tai Chanh here and it is HELLA bomb. They use wagyu for their pho so I highly recommend ordering your steak "on the side" just to prevent it from overcooking in the bowl while you take your pictures for Instagram.

My normal go-to is Pho Dac Biet which is done just right. The broth is absolutely delicious and not too salty. Their Bun Bo Hue is also packed with flavor, definitely no skimping on spices here!
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Being a Vietnamese American, I love being able to find places that remind me home, and my mom's cooking. I must say that Golden Lotus has everything I look for in a Vietnamese restaurant: cleanliness, impecable service, delicious food, and no cash only requirement. Yes, that's right. They accept cards! 

I've tried both the bun rieu from here and Pho 2000 and just say the one at Golden Lotus, this one is far more superior. They give you a large serving of crab, 2-3 shrimps, and a lot of cha (not sure what the English pronunciation is). A small bowl is $8.95 which is a little higher than Pho 2000 but it's definitely worth it! 

I've also had the banh uot here which is phenomenal and definitely reminds me of home as well due to the perfect taste of their fish sauce. If you're around the tenderloin, have no cash on you and want to be reminded of your mom's cooking, stop by this place and check it out!
author: My N.

description:
Golden Lotus is my favorite place for pho in San Francisco. 

Why? 

Their wagyu beef noodle soup is amazing. Get it with their regular flat noodles and enjoy the delicate texture of the meat. I didn't crave pho much until I came here.

The place looks small, but there's additional seating available in the back room. Service is very friendly and the place is clean, which is a plus in the neighborhood.
author: Keane L.

description:
It was decent, but eh, idk i think pho in SF just doesn't compare to San Jose...
Its a typically small joint. there was a line out the door at lunch time on a weekday. but we were able to beat the line by going thru a secret entrance...That's all i'm gonna say =X

First off, was kinda annoyed the tables were so sticky, no amount of napkins were making a difference. Same thing with the chopsticks...We ended up just fishing for chopsticks until we found ones that weren't sticky. The sauce cups were also dirty.

Everyone was raving about the lemongrass pork rice rolls, so I had to order. It was decent, and unique from the typical spring rolls, but nothing epic. Wouldn't order it again.

I was craving spicy and got the bunbohue.. i've had better broth in San Jose. It was a light, clean broth, but wasn't particularly satisfying. I did like the quality of the beef, steamed pork, and tendons though. 

I convinced my coworker to get the pho ga, since he's never had chicken pho before. and he really enjoyed the broth. I had some of his 5 spice chicken, which came in a separate plate, and it was yummy. I didn't try his soup though.

All in all, a decent place for pho. but not sure if I would come again.
author: Angela C.

description:
Came here for dinner with some friends right before seeing Aladdin at the Orpheum which is a couple blocks away. We wanted Vietnamese, but the place we were planning to go to originally was closed on Wednesdays, so we ended up coming here, and I'm really glad we did! Everyone really enjoyed their food.

We arrived around 6:30 on a Wednesday. Even though the restaurant wasn't that big, only half of it was full, so my group of 5 was able to get seated immediately.

As a typical Vietnamese spot, they have a decent selection of pho, vermicelli, and rice dishes. I wasn't that hungry so I was looking for something light. Ended up going for a small beef stew (#31) for $8.95. You can pick from a couple different types of noodle, which is nice.

My beef stew noodle soup was exactly what I wanted. The beef was cut in small, easily chewable chunks and extremely well flavored. I love beef stew cuts as it is very common in Chinese cuisine, but sometimes it can be dry, which wasn't the case here at all. Everything else (the soup, noodles) was great as well, and even though I wasn't that hungry, I ended up finishing every single last bite.

My friends ordered a variety of pho and vermicelli dishes, and we all agreed at the end that our food was great.

I'll definitely have to remember this spot and come back for some of their other dishes.
author: Dianna H.

description: This place is amazing. Its the best Vietnamese food I've had outside of Vietnam. The family that runs it is insanely lovely, and everything on the menu is amazing!
author: L. B.

description:
I would say this place looks pretty good, it's cleaner and brighter than most places in the TL. The food is pretty good too. You would think places in the TL would be cheaper than other places in the city (due to location), but it's about the same price. I would say you get a little bit more noodles than other Vietnamese restaurants.

I usually get pho with everything! They use waygu beef (so they say), I honestly can't tell. Last time I got bun rieu and it was so good! It tasted like salted shrimp paste!

I'll be back!
author: Kylie L.

description:
Came here for dinner because it was around the corner from our hotel, hotel epik. 

They were becoming pretty packed for a sat night, and we ordered really quickly. I ordered the pho small size with all the toppings,  my friends ordered the veggie pho and the vermicelli noodle with egg rolls and roasted chicken. 

The food was decently portioned and affordably priced. The veggie pho had a great veggie tasting broth that wasn't salty at all, and was also chock full of veggies. The vermicelli noodles had alot of toppings and i really enjoyed the few bites i grabbed from my friends plates.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I've repeatedly given Golden Lotus tries because it's popular among my coworkers and I gotta say I do like the space of Golden Lotus because there's so many tables and it's relaxing atmosphere.

Last time I went I ordered the Banh Uot and it was delicious. I'm thinking about what to get for lunch today and remembering it from last time, I'll probably get it today!

So I'm thinking my first time, I must've just ordered the wrong thing or they had an off day.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Given how the Tenderloin isn't exactly my favorite neighborhood in SF (to put it kindly...sorry), I usually need a good reason to come out this way.  A hot date would do it, but something tasty works just as well.  The likes of Lers Ros and Anh Hong?  I'd gladly come out here for them (or a hot Korean girl, but that's beside the point).  However, with apologies to my buddy's girlfriend, who strongly recommended this place to us, Golden Lotus falls short of joining that esteemed company for me...

Located in Turtle Tower's original digs, Golden Lotus doesn't look all that special on the surface, other than feeling a bit cleaner than its predecessor.  However, after giving the menu a once over, I could see the appeal.  The range of dishes is standard (appetizers, pho, bun, and rice plates), but within those categories, there are some interesting dishes to be had.  It's not often you see legit options like Banh Xeo (Vietnamese crepe), Bun Mam (Vietnamese "gumbo"), and Banh Uot (rice noodle sheets with fancy pork)!

-- (#3) BANH CUON THIT NUONG - Rice Rolls with Grilled Lemongrass Pork, Mint, and Fried Shallots...$7
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-lotus-san-francisco?select=a1dMLokBwUmjmgbqLXyDOw)
Not every Vietnamese restaurant offers this, so I was pretty excited to try it.  Unfortunately, it missed the mark for me.  The rice roll itself was fine, but I didn't care much for the meat.  It wasn't bad, per se, but I didn't care for the seasoning, especially in terms of all the lemongrass.

-- (#2) CHA GIO - Imperial Rolls with Pork, Shrimp, Mushroom, Taro, Jicama, and Glass Noodles...$7.75
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-lotus-san-francisco?select=-qAn9eH946UEAysjk1F36A)
When our order came out, we were pleasantly surprised by the portion size - six rolls!  A lot more bag for the buck than my favorite (PPQ's in the Sunset), but not quite as tasty.  The filling was pretty decent, but the wrapper/skin was off.  It was crispy on the outside, but the inner layers were kind of gummy.

-- (#21) PHO DAT BIET - Combination of Rare Steak, Flank, Brisket, Tripe, Tendon, and Beef Balls...$9.85 (large)
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-lotus-san-francisco?select=KVuhH0F6OIetcAp3llv8qw)
Setting aside how it was a little heavy on cilantro (ugh...), this was...okay.  The rare steak was fantastic and I liked the flank steak, but nothing else stood out.  It felt a little light on the noodles and meat, but my bigger qualm was with the broth.  It wasn't exactly bland, but it was kind of generic and wasn't very deep/rich.

Beyond the food, I thought the service here was great!  The workers were all very nice and quite accommodating when my friend wanted to modify her order.  At the same time though, I can't say the food was particularly unique.  Solid, but not unique...nor something I'd come back to the TL for specifically.  While I'd come back to try their Banh Xeo or Bun Mam, if I'm out this way, I'd probably lean towards trying something new instead.  Sorry [buddy's girlfriend]!
author: Mike L.

description: Amazing food! I was so shocked! It's a little sketchy in the area but don't be alarmed the food and service is amazing! I got the BUn_Tom_Thit_Nuong number 43 on the menu I def suggest this meal! Everything was cooked to perfection
author: Larry M.

description: Although inexpensive, careful with what you're given In addition, it's a tough neighborhood and filthy sidewalks with homeless persons and drug addicts frequently nearby! Also, be careful what you are about to step on in the walkway
author: Don J.

description:
Most of the places in Little Saigon are cash-only, but who carries just cash now anymore? Golden Lotus takes card, and the food is a great cure for a hangover. Honestly, a pretty smart business tactic. 

When you get the pho, ask for their special hand-pulled noodles! It's not on the menu, but the wide, chewy texture is worth waiting for. I'd also recommend the grilled pork with imperial rolls served with vermicelli. Ever since I traveled to Vietnam, I've been looking for good bun cha. Obviously, nothing here can compare, but it's good nonetheless. The staff is very friendly and responsive, plus it's cheap!
author: Arielle I.

description:
Good, solid broth.
The owners are nice and don't yell (unlike almost 99% of other vietnamese restaurants). They're Chinese speaking (maybe also vietnamese?) and asked me how my meal was at the end :O

Their default noodle is a flatter rice noodle, unlike the typical thin rice noodle we get at most pho places. If you have a preference, be sure to let them know you'd like the thin rice noodle instead.

They have a bathroom here.
author: Sally L.

description: Can't go wrong with the 21 or 22 here. Check this place out! They are fantastic!
author: Michael C.

description:
It's located in Tenderloin , sketchy area,  but the resto and their food look clean enough and very fair price. 

Normally i'm not a big fan of Pho but i like vermicelli dishes here 

No.43 and 44 are my fav 

The food came fast and the portion is big enough for making my belly
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
Came here for lunch with my bae. Loves the beef pho, the broth is cooked to perfection just like a home cooked meal from Mom. I had the beef stew with the thick ho fun which was perfect. The taste, quality of the beef was tender and I love the tendon. Everything was proportioned and I couldn't even finish my small bowl.
They do not compromise on quality or quantity of their food. If your looking for a quick fix for lunch or late night, this is the place to be.
author: Tina L.

description:
Their "Pho" is pretty much authentic. They let yoi choose the noodles: slim or thick. In the North of Vietnam where Pho is original from, pho is the flat and about 1/4 of an inch wide, soft and white. So if you like to go authentic then ask for the wider noodles. 
The broth is good and their herbs are fresh. Can't imagine my winter without their Pho after work. 
Love it.
author: Le T.

description: Another amazing, cheap option for pho in the Tenderloin's Little Saigon. Plus, they take card. Win-win!! Their pho is really, really good. The broth is perfect, all the herb fixings, and plenty of beef, tendon and tripe. I LOVE when they give you tendon and tripe without charging extra. Definitely get the large bowl, since you get significantly more for just a dollar more.
author: Ke C.

description: I came here on a weekday so we had no wait.  I ordered the chicken pho soup and boy, it was delicious! It was almost comparable to Turtle Tower.  The service, like other Asian restaurants, are okay but if you come here for the pho, I don't think you would be disappointed.  The noodles were the thick kind and were soft in texture.  The chicken and the soup were scrumptious-- not too salty like others.  I am so glad I live close by so I can come here for lunch more often.
author: Kristy L.

description: To-go food on a busy Saturday night. Gracious service, but the food was just OK. We ordered pho and imperial rolls, both vegetarian and meat.
author: Camille L.

description:
Review is for Pho Only

Tragically mediocre. The broth is watery and salty, an odd compromise between Northern and Southern style that captures the best features of neither. The knife work is shoddy at best, and the quality of the beef is not up to par. The noodles are complete mush with an unpleasant texture-- they lack substance. The restaurant also lacks charm compared to other hole in the walls in the area. For Pho, look elsewhere.
author: David H.

description:
Ate dinner there with my wife. Had the Grilled pork and Imperial roll "Bun"/vermicelli dish. Enjoyed it very much. Meat was plentiful, and the other ingredients were fresh and well-prepared. 
Suggestion: Perhaps they can offer option to pay $1 more and get an extra Imperial Roll?
Service was very good and friendly.
Appears to be family-owned and I got the impression that they are very nice people.
Neighbourhood might be a bit sketchy after dark.
author: Shaheen T.

description: I was *that* person who came in 30 min before close.... Service was fast, food was tasty and prices cheap especially considering the amount of food! I had the pho with meatballs and brisket. It had a little sweetness to the brother I'm not used to, but overall really good. I definitely would go back if I'm in the area.
author: Nana S.

description:
The great thing about Little Saigon is that if the pho place you've set out to try has a wait, there are tons of other 4-star options.  I hadn't planned on coming to Golden Lotus, but they had space in the backroom and I was hungry for pho right then.  Didn't disappoint.

Pho Bo: Broth was so rich and comforting on an overcast San Francisco day.  I got my typical mix of rare steak, brisket, flank and meatballs.  Some people just don't like tendon and tripe, so deal with it!  There was a very generous portion of meat overall.  Loads of brisket, more meatballs than other places though a tad light on the rare steak.   Noodles were nice and al dente.  Great way to hit the spot.
author: Adam B.

description:
Always reliable, always fresh, always tasty. Nothing spectacular and not spectacularly cheap, but a good deal for downtown SF, and a standout in an unimpressive sea of mostly overrated pho houses. This is the old location for the old Turtle Tower, before it cashed in for a profitable chain with a business plan. All the best to those guys but apparently my loyalty is to buildings, not restaurants, and this one remains great.

The main draw for me here is the pho chay, probably the best bowl of vegetarian pho I've had in the Bay. They stack it full of broccoli, tofu, and other green things and overpack it with unremarkable but perfectly serviceable rice noodles--I always go with the thick ones. Criss-cross the broth a few times with sriracha and hoisin and you're on your way to a flavorful meal that will satisfy without veering toward excess.

Service is prompt, respectful, and efficient. And if I've never raved about their menu, I've also managed to return here many times without complaint, itself something to rave about.
author: James D.

description: Combo Pho was what I order. Pho broth was good but when I got my pho it wasn't hot. I can slurp the broth without it burning my mouth. Even my steak didn't cook throughly. When I asked for a side broth it was hot and my meat cooked thoroughly. I like my food hot and it wasn't hot, 3 stars because customer service was good.
author: Cindy M.

description: Awesome veggie selection! This will definitely be my go to spot for Vietnamese food when I'm downtown. Absolutely delicious!
author: Sabrina C.

description:
Like a 3.5 ish, almost a 4 because of the water, almost just a 3 cuz of the lack of veggies. The spot has people popping in during the lunch hour, the food comes out hot and quick. Service with water was actually quite attentive, I almost want to give a 4 just cuz of that haha. 

Anyway, I had a large 32, the vegetarian pho. I should've just gotten the regular, totally forgot that the large only gives you more broth and noodles and not more of the toppings to go with it. With that being said, there was a ton of noodles. The broth was good and hot as well. Always a fan the broth being the right temperature for me. I was disappointed in there not being much vegetable wise. Like cool, you brought out one tiny plate of bean sprouts and leaves for a whole table of 4 but generally that just wouldn't cut it.

Maybe I'm just getting ahead of myself. Skimping on veggies is actually somewhat normal, I would just want more given the price. The broth was good at least, I just might get a meat dish instead to make things more worth. Or try the stir fry version to see if the same amount is given on the rice plate. We'll see if I end up over here again sometime.
author: David C.

description:
I guess I'm a little biased to review this restaurant, seeing as our group goes here so often that the owner and waitresses not only know us by name but have memorized all of our orders.  It's just so casual now that we don't even enter from the front entrance, but we sneak around the back to our own tables.  Service, obviously, is top-notch once you get to know them.

Anyway, my favorite is #42, the typical vermicelli noddles with beef and imperial rolls that you'd find in nearly any Vietnamese restaurant.  Not exactly groundbreaking, but it'll fill you well, and I've noticed their meat is slightly more tender than other restaurants.  However, the reason you should go to GL is #62.  It's a special Vietnamese catfish stew; it's my friend's favorite and his exclusive order.  He's Vietnamese and despite having gone to Vietnamese joints around the city, we've never found the thing anywhere else.  Though it's not exactly my bowl of pho (does that work as an idiom?), my friend swears that it tastes like it's homemade.

I admit that this place isn't exactly in the best of areas (lots of homeless or shady folks around...which is fine for us, since we eat here after our homeless ministry), so make sure you practice safety outside the restaurant.  All in all, even though this place is flanked by an army of other local Vietnamese restaurants within the same block, it's still our favorite in the area.
author: Matthew W.

description:
I crave a big beautiful bowl of pho noodle soup for breakfast sometimes -especially to pacify a morning hangover.  The problem lies with most joints who simply don't open early enough for breakfast.  9am was perfect for me and my fiancé.

I set my eyes on #22 rare steak pho and ordered some hot tea.  My honey followed suit, and together our depleted energy had returned with all the warm, hearty goodness a delicious bowl of pho has to offer.  Although, we both chose the thin rice noodles, they offer the rice stick or egg noodles also which is nice to have as other options. 

The rare steak in this pho was most excellent.  While most are somewhat dry and lack flavor, Golden Lotus rare steak was soft, fresh and flavorful thin meat slices.  It was as if I ordered quality beef for shabu!  The broth was perfect (apparently wagyu beef broth), but neither of us could consume the entire cauldron set before us.  All the bean sprouts, basil and jalapeño slices were devoured with the noodles and tasty meat between us though!

Additionally, to the excellent pho we had here, these guys are really nice and friendly.  They're not detached from the serving experience like many Chinese/Vietnamese restaurants.  We were asked how everything was and given smiles.  In return, they got a nice tip from us. This restaurant is also very clean.  The bathroom is a testament to this.

I will have to have another bowl of pho here if not try some of their other dishes on my next visit.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I tried the Bun Bo Hue because it seemed a lot of people ordered this here. The Bun Bo hue broth was mediocre (I am Vietnamese) , but the portion was huge. 

Also the server, Han, was pretty cute.
author: Tung D.

description: I really liked the vegetarian pho they have. I got it with the wide noodles and for once I was full after eating pho. They also have the fastest service I have ever experienced. You will literally get your food faster here than at McDonalds.
author: Ben E.

description:
They've definitely improved! I don't know if there's been a change in ownership or just recipe tweaking but whatever is going on is working for me. 

Recently had pho and ordered a large. First of all, my eyes were bigger than my stomach. They don't play around. It is huge. You know how most places just give you more broth but the same amount of noodles? Not here! Hellaaaaa noodles! 

I almost always ask for my steak on the side. Menu said they use wagyu (this was new to me) and the steak is pretty tender and has nice marbling of fat. 

Couldn't finish my bowl because I drank most the soup. It was pretty good! Broth has improved.
author: Susy C.

description: We eat here at least once a week, sometimes twice.  We've never been disappointed. Friendly staff, delicious simple Vietnamese food well prepared and quick. Great place for a mixed group to eat... And by mixed I mean vegetarians and meat eaters.
author: Keith J.

description: My sister came here for lunch and got takeout for me. The spring rolls with grilled pork (highly recommended by the staff/owner) were so delicious! Supposedly this is the only restaurant that has this specific spring roll. Although I didn't dine in person, I was told that the service was great and the staff are very kind.
author: Joanne H.

description:
Came here for lunch because pho 2000 was closed. My boyfriend and I ordered five spice chicken pho, beef pho and a vegetarian banh xeo.
We noticed the waiter was not paying attention to our order and when the food came out.. the banh xeo had pork inside. I do not eat pork. We informed the waiter and he apologized and took the banh xeo back. When he came out with a "vegetarian" banh xeo, it was the same one they had previously made but the kitchen staff picked out 85% of the pork. They did not make a fresh one, or even bother to take out all the pork. I have never been to an establishment that does this sort of bs.
author: Louise X.

description: The beef pho is so-so. The pho noodles are way too thick and the quality of meat is mediocre. The rice plates look like a better option. The banh xeo is a good, crispy thin Vietnamese crepe, but filled with too much bean sprouts and not enough shrimp, with only a few small pieces.
author: Beth K.

description:
First impressions (food starts next paragraph): Dropped in on a whim. It was my birthday and I was having Asian food extravaganza. After going to Wing Lee for dim sum and Japantown for a Thai Tea with boba, boyfriend and I went to Sai Jai Thai, and then I wanted Vietnamese. I didn't realize there were so many Thai and Vietnamese places so close to each other, but after getting most of our Thai food in a to-go box, we walked around the corner to find this and another Vietnamese restaurant next door to one another. The first place was pretty small and pretty full. We grabbed a paper menu and stepped outside to look at it. We poked our heads into the next restaurant, and the friendly man behind the register walked all the way out to the sidewalk to try to usher is in. Sometimes this bugs me, but this time I found it endearing. The place had about ten tables; only one or two others had patrons when we entered around 7:15pm, but most of them were being used by the time we left a bit before 8:30.

Though the waitress strongly recommended the imperial rolls, I had my heart set on spring rolls, which were delicious (as expected). The peanut sauce that came with them was also just right (I really appreciate it when a server lets me know what they like on the menu).
I asked for her advice on which meat to get in my bun (vermicelli), though I usually always get pork. She suggested pork, as if it was no-brainer. The pork was sliced almost razor thin; I had rolling foodgasms. I couldn't stop eating even when I was full, it was just too delicious.
I got a Thai Iced Tea and boyfriend got a Vietnamese coffee. Both were delicious, the coffee so strong, as they usually are. When I finally was able to pull my face out of my bowl of food, I asked for a to-go box. The waitress even brought a small container for peanut sauce and then when the amount I had left didn't fill it, she basically insisted on giving me more, with more crushed peanuts on top.

The entire experience was great, I've been singing the praises of this restaurant, the servers, the food, the atmosphere, everything about it in general. Even the neighborhood isn't a turn off because most, um, homeless and/or less than fully mentally competent people mostly keep to themselves, or are friendly rather than scary. I'll probably end up making another trip to the city just to try the pho that I'm reading about in other reviews.

Five stars across the board.
author: Delia F.

description:
Every Time I have my nails done, always crave for Pho, don't know why. Not every day but only on that day ;)
I have my favorite I casually went however; they closed today and I cannot not have one. I went to Lee's Sandwiches to get me something to forget the sweet tasty touch of raw beef on Pho soup. Not helping! Then I noticed an opened one and decided to give them a try.
Very clean, a small place and not many customers in that afternoon so staff was quite attentive. Noodle brought out fast. Smell delicious and hot.
I would say that the Pho broth is not one of the best I have had BUT the size is incredible. So fulfilling. I had an extra broth with special cow's parts and the broth tasted so good?! I assumed it came from the same pot(?) then it must have been my fault for mixing too much Hoishin sauce in Pho noodle?!? 
Good price, awesome size. And they even have 'tit canh' Oh my Gosh!!!!!!
author: Bao V.

description: Great pho soup, fast good staff, reasonable, great steak in the soup,   Not a fancy location, but clean.  Give it a try
author: Julie H.

description: I love coming here. It's super convenient. I get to sit down but not have to wait super long. I bring my roommate here who is vegetarian so she could try vegetarian pho for the first time and she loved it!
author: Sara S.

description:
This is my #2 spot for pho in the TL. I've eaten and to-goed food here on multiple occasions and it never disappoints. The service is superb, food always comes out quick! 

When you order noodle, you have the option of choosing the thin or thicker noodles (to your preference), which is great, most Vietnamese restaurants don't give you that option or don't inform you that you can do that. I've also tried the rice plate with pork chops and a side of veggies and the pork chops are huge! (and they give you two). 

PARKING: street, can be hard to find. Also in the TL so it's kind of sketch so be careful. 

PRICE: typical price you would see at a Vietnamese restaurant, reasonable 

SERVICE: amazing
author: Vivian S.

description:
Food: I ordered the bun rieu which is probably the worst bun rieu I've had at a restaurant. Both the broth and the meat lacked flavor. Though I did like the addition of cha lua (pork roll slices) in the soup. 2/5

Service: Fair. Our waiter was neither friendly or rude. 3/5

Final Thoughts: I would come back to try other dishes but I do not recommend the bun rieu.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Genuine Vietnamese dishes, fresh, tasty ingredients and a very clean place. Their beef salad was delicious (order rice or noodles with it as it is essentially raw beef) as was their green papaya salad. Also had their "bi cuon" and since it is an appetizer that many Americans don't care for, they kindly asked me if I had had it before.
author: Renee M.

description: Wow!! Their Bun Mam is soooo good, if you're Vietnamese, you def should know what this noodle dish is. It has a pungent fishy smell to its broth but when you taste it, it's delicious. A true Vietnamese person would know the taste of this rich bowl. Love it, will come again!!
author: Ritney N.

description: I came here on my lunch break, I was craving pho, and this was the only place around that wasn't cash only. I ordered the rare beef pho, the beef was yummy..it said it was wagyu beef on the menu. I loved that there was an option for the thicker rice noodle.
author: Sherry F.

description:
This is one of the many pho places within 2 blocks.  I had a large pho tai with rare beef slices and flank.  It was just ok.  The broth was a little lighter than Pho 2000 a few doors down but this could have been a matter of timing.  The beef itself was bland and dry but at least it was very lean.

The service was very attentive.  They stopped by several times to offer tea and water and addressed everything from extra lemons to dropping of the bill expediently.  A nonstop stream of diners drifted in and out of the place, even at 2PM on a weekday, a testament to the value of the food this place dishes up.  

Solid but not memorable.
author: Amy J.

description: This is a hole in the wall place in the Tenderloin. I had the seafood pho and it was delicious. The soup alone is tasty enough to cure all ails
author: Brandon M.

description: I ordered a small bowl of Pho Bo Vien (pho with meatballs). The broth was a little oily but I prefer that over being salty. They use long, flat noodles here which is a bit different than what I'm used to but I don't mind it at all. They do accept credit cards over here but be aware that they have a $10 minimum.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
This place is so amazing. 
Get the 5 spice chicken pho, and instead of adding sriracha, ask for their chili paste. Thank me later.
author: Ana P.

description: I came here around 7 with my family. It's not that big of a restaurant, but when we came it was only half full. I ordered the pho ga (chicken pho) and it was amazing. I've never had any chicken pho that was as good as the one here. Even though I was full halfway, I managed to eat the entire bowl because it was delicious. Good service and fast wait times!
author: Bonnie T.

description: Good and cheap food. Their ingredients were very fresh, pho, bun thit nuong and banh cuon thit nuong were delicious! Would definitely pick this place over Pho 2000 as it is definitely cleaner. If you're looking for variety of Vietnamese place, this is a great place to try.
author: Linda L.

description:
The food is elevated, also. If I could eat here, everyday I totally would. Their pho has more meat in it than usual, so you feel like you're getting a deal! Haha.I've only had the Pho (steak, and dac biet) and spring rolls.

People there are friendly and the tables have enough room between them to feel like a restaurant and not a food factory. I prefer this place over Turtle Tower because the food feels more homemade. Recently, some of the 20 something lazy waiters are dragging their feet. I find it's easiest to be direct with them.

One day, when I can afford to live in the TL (teehee), I will spend my evenings here, looking out the window, pretending I'm Keri Russell in Felicity and this is the time of my life. slurpslurpslurp
author: Chris L.

description: I love their imperial rolls the best in the TL. The pho was just okay. Good quality beef but you don't get much.
author: K C.

description:
The best pho I've ever had hands down and I've had a lot of pho!!!! It's also extremely reasonably priced ~$10 for a large bowl. They're consistently open late throughout the week.

Their broth is my favorite and doesn't feel like I'm ingesting MSG. 

I always get the rare beef large bowl and THIN NOODLES. Not a fan of be thick noodles. 

They also give generous, fresh portions of jalapeños, bean sprouts, and lime.

The owner is super friendly and awesome.
author: Connie W.

description:
2 1/2 stars.  Last min decision to come here because pho 2000 was closed.  I know I've been spoil because pho 2000, and Parilla is my fav Vietnamese in SF.  
GL your beef pho was actually OK but you are stingy on the jalapeno, and lime which was not fresh.  Whatever little basil was there have 2 bad, black spoil leaves on them.  The cold vermicelli pork and imperial rolls could have been better.  Come on, old wilted lettuce that's should be thrown out a week ago which I have to pick off in order to eat it otherwise would have make me sick.  Mint was black; lost mint flavor a long time ago.  Should have leave it out if its too old.  Imperial roll should have fried a little more because it wasn't crispy.  The sauce that comes with it was not salty or sour enough, I think I can make a better sauce and it wasn't enough to season the vermicelli.   GL could have been OK if just take care and pay attention to details.  Would you eat the spoiled veg??? I dare you to.
author: Mar H.

description:
We tried to go to Turtle Tower initially, but they're closed on Sunday's. Then we tried Pho 2000, but it's cash only. So let's just say Golden Lotus wasn't our first choice (or second), however we were pleasantly surprised!

The pho here is fresh, tasty and affordable. I particularly really like the fresh wide noodles they serve with their pho. (You can request thinner noodles if you want, I believe.) Service was also really good as well. 

I'd definitely come back if I'm ever in the area!
author: Laverne N.

description:
I like this pho place. I've been here a few times for take out. This time I got a chance to eat here. 

The service is great! They are very friendly. The restaurant is clean for being located in TL. It's kinda a small place, but the service is very fast.  

We ordered the Goi Cuong for starters. I have to say, they where really good! We also got the Pho Tai, and the BBQ Pork with Rice and Egg. 
The pho noodles where the thick egg noodles. I was expecting the regular thin noodles, but it was good. The broth was delicious. The bean sprouts and mint for the pho was very fresh; unlike some other Vietnamese restaurants. 

I definitely will come back here if I'm in the mood for Vietnamese food in TL. And they take credit cards! Most Vietnamese places only take cash. So that is a huge plus.
author: Edie G.

description:
The spring rolls (fresh shrimp and pork) are so crisp and refreshing. The mint is just right. We stop in once a week for an order.

Friendly, fast, affordable.
author: Josh W.

description: Cheap and delicious Pho, cold noodles, and the typical fare. Fresh and very expertly assembled.
author: Michael J S.

description:
Craving my favorite Vietnamese noodle soup, my friend and I decided to come here for lunch. The restaurant doesn't look the cleanest, but I've learned the best Vietnamese restaurants are those that look rundown. I ordered a bowl of bun rieu and somehow the waitress convinced my friend and I to order their lemongrass beef rice rolls. 

The rice rolls were surprising very good and they came with fish sauce on the side. The only thing I didn't like was how much they charged for 2 rolls. Then, our bun rieus came out and it looked really promising. I grew up eating the bun rieu that my family occasionally made, so I had high standards when it comes to bun rieu. Unfortunately, I was disappointed. The soup lacked the flavor that makes this noodle soup so addicting. 

Overall the service was great. If I were to come here again, I would try their pho or vermicelli noodles.
author: Melanie H.

description: Awesome Vietnamese food and friendly staff! Also, it's open early for the hung over Phó.
author: Joel B.

description:
Lunch on a weekday, Banh Uot (wide rice noodles w/ meat and veggies) & Bun Mam (broth made w/ fermented fish) at our table. Banh Uot noodles were fresh but the wrong kind, the cha lua (VN pork sausage) was a sub standard example, fried onion topping was scarce.

Ms. Young Server seemed to be very unhappy. My Vietnamese tablemate who had the Bun Mam reported the only thing good about it was that it was hot (broth not proper, fish not proper, noodles OVER cooked). I had Banh Uot and it was a poor representation.

Not sure what happened to this joint since my last visit about 2 years ago, but it has taken a dive, and now offers no reason to return.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Avoid at all cost.  There are way better pho places in this neighborhood. Waited 70 minutes for our food. Pho came out cold. Forgot our appetizers.  Go somewhere else.
author: Shawn S.

description:
I was very saddened that I never had that opportunity to eat at the old Turtle Tower location.  

Well, it is never too late to start a new chapter of the new Golden Lotus. 

On my debut of the new restaurant, I had the Five Spice Chicken over rice. For $8.00, I get slices of marinated grilled chicken with the dipping sauce, heaping scoop of rice and fresh greens. For another $2.00, I also added shredded pork and an over-easy egg. You can easily tell I was hungry. But this is a solid rice dish for a heavy-eater like me. 

The conversion of the new restaurant is whole lot better now. The place is clean with no adhesive floors or funky odors like some restaurants in the area. The staff was very friendly to Joe Cool. 

Credit card is accepted for over $10.00. My hefty dish was good enough for the transaction.

Expect more visits and check-ins from me.
author: Matt G.

description:
Much better than Ha Nam Ninh many times over. Their floors are not slippery from grease, their staff aren't rude like hell and they actually come to the table and refill drinks. 

Their staff is on the slow side. We came here for lunch and everywhere else was packed. The food was very decent just the time between coming and leaving makes an hour lunch not enough.
author: M C.

description: Being Vietnamese, I find I'm very picky when it comes to Vietnamese food but this is my go-to spot! I have yet to try something that disappoints. I've tried their bun rieu, bun bo hue, spring rolls (both the traditional shrimp and the bbq ones), egg rolls, vermicelli bowls, rice plates, pho obviously and their banh uot. Sauces can really make or break a dish and their fish sauce is perfect, not bland or too sweet/sour. Their peanut sauce is amazing too! Service is always fast and friendly.
author: Raeann L.

description: i dunno why, but not a lot of vietnamese restaurants in the tenderloin are open at night.  i came here the other day and shared the bun w/ grilled pork and egg rolls and the bun rieu.  i thought bun rieu was supposed to have crab in it, but this one did not.  the grilled pork bun was good, but i think they skimped a bit on the meat.
author: Helen T.

description:
Beware to all hipsters: if you are one that cares about ambiance, perfectly chiseled fine oak tables and drinks served in mini sizes mason jars, this place is not for you. This place is, of no frills and just that. But this place has got their act together and has their priorities in tact; they know how to make their Vietnamese food.

Get your Bun Bo Hue fix here. Get a small size, unless you have been starving for days: it is packed with bottomless meat and heavenly broth that has been boiled for hours.
author: Al L.

description: Come here for the pho ga. The regular pho, not the best but definitely edible. Ask for their onions in vinegar and you'll enjoy your meal. They also have fresh chilis; just have to ask for it.
author: Marlene T.

description:
It's the shop that would be Turtle Tower...or so it seems would be their aspiration (photo: http://bit.ly/1j4YDvo). Even the new Turtle Tower is not like the old Turtle Tower. As with any Asian noodle house, it's all in the broth. Master it and you will have the queue out the door for days. But if you don't, well, expect some shrugs among your diners. I was a bit of a shrugger when I came in here since I was hoping for Turtle Tower redux. Not quite. I was probably put off by the service a bit. I was seated at one table ready to order when I was told to get up and move to another to accommodate a young family of five that chaotically came in through the door well after me.

Normally I'm not put off by such requests, but it was the indifferent way the veteran waitress just took my water glass and scowled at me to get up that made me feel less than special. Oh well, at least they took my order soon after that instead of ignoring me as I feared they would at my hidden corner table. I decided upon the $8.15 bowl of Bun Ro Hue, as it lured me with a combination of beef shank and pork tendon with a bit of lemongrass and a lot of MSG thrown in for good measure (photo: http://bit.ly/1gFCvHz). What I didn't count on was the fiery spiciness of the broth which I didn't take notice of on the menu. Ay chihuahua! Anyway, it was decent, and the next time, I plan to rent some kids.

FOOD - 3 stars...that's some spicy pho but it lacks a certain richness
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...doesn't look much different from the old Turtle Tower
SERVICE - 2 stars...need to ding them for treating me like Anne Frank before she got her diary
TOTAL - 3 stars...a passably good bowl of pho in a neighborhood with exceptionally good ones
author: Ed U.

description: Vegit Vietnamese place with menu items not found in mainstream spots, i.e. this sour catfish soup I ordered, which was interesting, in a good way! Huge pieces of fish, some green vegetable I've never come across before, and an overall very hefty serving. Pork fresh rolls were also delicious.
author: Shendi X.

description:
Food (4/5): My bf and I got the lemongrass beef rice rolls, pho ga (chicken pho), pho w/ meatballs and beef, and extra veggies. I really liked the rice rolls, which were refreshing and flavorful. Pho was also good! They really packed in the meat and veggies. I'm not a pho expert at all, but I thought both the chicken and beef broths were yummy.

Service (4/5): Service is pretty good - sometimes the servers disappear in the back for a while but other than that no complaints. We were seated right away and our food came out fast!

Value (4/5): The large portion is less than $10 and was enough for 2 meals!
author: Abby S.

description:
Ordered the chicken pho. Nothing spectacular. The chicken had the skin still on it, which I'm sure gives it more flavor, but I prefer without. They only provided one little plate of toppings for two people so we asked for more, but they never came. The broth wasn't as flavorful or aromatic as I expected, more of a boiled  chicken flavor. 

Also had an order of egg rolls that were the saving point of the meal. 

Service: sub par; every request aggrevated the situation. As noted above, had to request an additional topping plate several times. One of the orders was incorrect and we were charged for their error, had to request the bill after they had cleared the table and didn't think to provide it on their own.
author: Marcela M.

description: Good pho, decent price and great service. It's not too far from BART and the food comes quickly. I recommend this place!
author: Kevin D.

description: This is our go to Pho place where the noodles are always fresh, piping hot soup just the way we like it. Devoted customers and love love love this place.
author: Jacqueline P.

description: The food is excellent, fresh and tasty. I arrived close to closing time and they were still happy to take care of us. I had the bowl which was hot and zesty, I enjoyed every bite, after adding in the fish and plum sauce. This place is divey and the neighborhood is a trashy but the service was great so I'd come again. I would readily recommend this place.
author: Jon O.

description:
N.style Vietnamese style beef pho - that's something you can't find anywhere in SF. If you're ok with MSG, there is tons of it in the broth, but it's good and heartwarming nonetheless.

Would suggest for pho, but not for spring rolls or bun.
author: Jess C.

description: I was practically raised in the OC (I'm from SoCal) where Viet food is delicious and no one does it better. And one dish I absolutely love is Bun Rieu, which I am never satisfied with unless my mother makes it because hers is the best (yeah I'm biased but its quality). I came here and instead of ordering pho like I usually would (since I have been eating it so much), I ordered bun rieu. The bun rieu came out smelling as it should with the right soup flavors I was looking for. I liked the noodles they used (super important to me) because they held so much flavor and the tomatoes were cooked just right. The most important part to me is always the meat and it was pretty decent. I really enjoyed the dish although it's not even close to being as good as my mother's. It's still better than my aunt's and other bowls I've tried. I'm pretty impressed with the bowl of bun rieu I got. I might try other dishes out but I'd rather just come out here to fill my bun rieu craving since I can't get it at home as often as I used to.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Weekday, 6 PM - Takeout

It's too bad that a lot of the great Vietnamese places around the Tenderloin close so early - I think only about a third stay open for dinner service.  So, if you wait until dinner time, your selection will be limited.  2 entrees and an appetizer ran between $25-30.  We got takeout, and I didn't have any complaints about the amount of time we waited for the food. The interior of the restaurant is what it is - they've done the best they could with what they got.

2. BANH CUON THIT NUONG - This was a great appetizer to start us off - rice rolls with grilled pork and a variety of vegetables, which were crisp and crunchy throughout.  They didn't skimp on the amout of meat, and the rice roll had a great texture.  The only negative was the dipping liquid - I would have much preferred peanut sauce here.  I guess it's just a preference, but I didn't enjoy the sweet/sour liquid that came with it.  

14. PHO TAIBO VIEN - This pho was not the best I've had, but also not the worst.  Probably worse than average - the salty/sour level was more than I would have liked.  Good amount of meat, and the beef balls were tasty.  The noodles were cooked well (and packed in a separate container), and they gave a lot of vegetables.  

43. BUN TAU HU CHAY - Vegetarian dish - the lemongrass tofu and shittake mushrooms were cooked a bit more than I would have liked, and was a little bland overall.  Full sauce action needed to enjoy this one.

I didn't really experience anything spectacular, and if I have this amazing pho that I read about, I'll update my review accordingly.  Will try to come out during the lunch hour to expand my selection a bit.
author: Ben K.

description:
I love this vegetarian restaurant. meat eaters like this place. It's our happy compromise. Golden lotus does it better than everyone. try their beefy-like strips with fried rice, YUmmy.  
favorite place.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: My favorite vietnamese restaurant in the TL. The lemongrass pork rolls are a must order!
author: M W.

description:
Golden Lotus to the rescue because they were open on Christmas day, and this is how Asians do Christmas (or I do at least).

I got the Pork and Imperial Roll Vermicelli and it was delicious! I ended up devouring the thing. Pork was flavorful, and imperial rolls didn't lag in taste either. 

Babe got the most basic pho there was and he seemed to enjoy it too. He got the beef on the side and it was most definitely legit/higher quality beef than you would get at some other Vietnamese pho restaurant (like the one in Westlake). 

Overall a pleasant experience here and I wouldn't mind coming back again.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Clean and simple restaurant.
I was looking for a place that accepts credit card nearby and it is the one, though there is a minimum limit. Customer service is nice and the noodles are better than what I expected. I had spicy beef noodles soup but it's not that spicy. It's manageable and delicious.
author: Joie H.

description: Pho ga might be better than Turtle Tower next door.  Less greasy.
author: John J.

description: Consistently great! Including for vegetarians.
author: Alex C.

description: The best Pho in town. We go EVERYWHERE in this city tracking down the place with the tastiest steak pho. We haven't had reason to keep searching since going to Golden Lotus. This place is amazing, and the staff is wonderful.
author: Hayden H.

description:
I was forced to try this place after almost collapsing into a fetal position upon seeing that my favorite pho place, Pho 2000, was closed. (Until November 13th, apparently!) Golden Lotus is located two doors down. I have tried four other pho places in a two block radius -- including Four Seasons, Bodega Bistro, Mangosteen, and Vietnam House. 

Pho 2000 is, by far, the best of them all by a mile. 

Golden Lotus having four stars on Yelp, helped alleviate some of my concerns. That was where the optimism ended. I typically get Pho Tai (Steak and Brisket), so that's what I'm basing most of my review on. First off, they didn't give me brisket, instead giving me tripe. I was too hungry to send it back, so I just started eating. I did tell them, however, so I wouldn't be charged an extra dollar (which they still did). Their broth was the darkest I'd ever seen and heavy (salty) on the flavor, which made tasting the nuances of sriracha, very difficult. Even squeezing lime into a spoonful of soup was disappointing. The steak did not easily break up from biting, requiring a bit of chewing. I like inhaling my food much better.

They made many other service mistakes, but it's really not that important. It's all about the pho. This place ranks #5, right before Vietnam House, which is last. #4 Four Seasons, #3 Mangosteen, #2 Bodega Bistro, #1 Pho 2000!
author: Kevin L.

description:
The pho here is such a game changer! I usually order the pho dac biet with beef on the side because I don't like my beef super well done. It usually gets tough and super chewy when it is. What I absolutely love about this place is that they serve Wagyu beef instead of regular, cheap, poor quality beef as compared to most pho restaurants. They easily give at least 6 pieces of Wagyu beef and it melts in your mouth. It's so delicious! There's also plenty of meat if you order dac biet (since dac biet is basically all of the meat they have to offer).  The noodles they serve are the thicker rice noodles but you can opt out for thin rice noodles or even egg noodles. I usually don't like the thicker noodles but I've grown to enjoy it with their flavorful and super hot broth! Besides pho, they also have different Vietnamese noodle soups such as bun rieu and bun bo hue. Other specialities such as banh xeo and rolled rice sheets. I'm definitely coming back to try these other items! 

The service here is also amazing. All of the employees are super nice and welcoming. They're very patient if you're unsure on what to order and they won't hesitate to give you recommendations if you ask. They greet you when you come in and when you leave. Nothing feels better than leaving a restaurant with a happy and full tummy and knowing that you have to go back soon.
author: Brenda K.

description:
Better than expected.  Pho noodle is not what you expect - it's more like a slimmer 'fun' rice noodle, which was a pleasant surprise for hubby.

My bun bo hue was not bad.  I asked for extra spicy, that didn't happen.  They do serve with the right sides (lotus flowers so that's a plus).  

The noodle roll w/ grilled pork was very good although presentation was non-existent.

Clean, fast and airy - no line, at least for us so all good.
author: Gloria H.

description:
First time coming here. My family and i only came here because the place we wanted to eat for lunch was close for vacation. Took them a while to bring out the menu. Dont have a lot of selection compare to other vietnamese restaurant. This place is clean and this place seem it just open recently since this place used to be the turtle tower restaurant. Friendly service and service was a bit slow since it was a bit busy

Order the pho dac biet, small size for 7.15. Thought it was alright. Its doable to eat. Feel like they might put some msg in the broth since i had that aftertaste and thirstiness after i finish eating it
author: Julie N.

description:
We stumbled into this place on accident because we wanted to try a new noodle spot.  This place is so good.  It is clean, and the owner is seriously the nicest man and always wears cool t-shirts his daughter buys him lol.  He was rocking Pink Floyd this weekend! 

Pho tai - the beef.  The beef is so tender and falls apart so easily.  YUM.  The broth is light, but packed with flavor.  This is definitely a go to.  Also, the clay pot dishes.  I also get the shrimp with crab paste and I always leave with a smile and wanting more!  The beef with eggplant clay pot is also equally delicious. 

This is a hidden gem in the TL, and it is as authentic as you can get :)
author: Kuanie J.

description:
I ordered vermicelli(imperial roll) and it was sooo goood!! 
Price was reasonable. The server was very friendly. 
The erea is pretty ghetto (very tenderloin)but I shall come back! 

I didn't try but they use WAGYU in their pho! 
(Wagyu is Japanese brand beef, which is very expensive. Since they labeled wagyu, it should be raised in Japan. ) 
I need to try!
author: Mii L.

description: It looks creepy but thus far my fave spot. Great flavors and quality of food. Don't let the neighborhood, or interior look fool you!
author: Kitty B.

description:
The area is kinda of dodgy...BUT this place is a gem :D.
Its clean! attentive staff! and boy can they make  a mean Vietnamese coffee.

For something light: 
GET the grilled chicken w/ imperial rolls
Banh Xeo its a turmeric crepe lettuce wrap with a unorthodox addition of calamari 
Pho ga w/ the feathers, gizzards, embryo egg, (in my honest opinion if you ever go to a pho joint and they offer you the free range "gà đi bo" walking the chicken version you best cough up that extra dollar and get it"

Heavy: Cannot go wrong with the old faithful grilled pork chop over rice topped with a runny egg

Overall it is an awesome establishment with quality food. I have yet to have a bad meal here. If i had to take my family out in this specific street for vietnamese  this would be it.
My only qualm about is their recent 1$ increase on everythang EVEN DRINKS!:(  
My asian stinginess has to take a star off otherwise it would have been 5/5
author: Harrison P.

description: My husband and I love this place for Pho. They're the best Vietnamese place I've been to, and I love their service anyone was very polite. The food was delicious. I have to say it was some of the best Pho I've had.
author: Lera W.

description: Delicious, authentic pho! My wife always goes for the bun bo hue and I get the pho ga. We've tried most of their appetizers and enjoyed them all. We're probably there twice a week on average. Great value!
author: Christopher J.

description:
Excellent!

The fresh spring rolls were the best I have ever had! The mint, cilantro, and a mouth watering peanut sauce dig were fabulous.

Entrees are well portioned and flavorful.

Homemade vegan cheese cake for desert....wow.

A must in SF
author: J G.

description: The chicken pho was sooooooo good. I was not expect to taste such chickeny and authentic pho broth here in america, it was yum yum yum. There were plenty of meat and herbs in the dish as well. Service is super nice and quick. Big thumbs up!!
author: Thuy T.

description:
Came here on a Friday night to grab dinner before the show.  My friends seemed excited about it so I was down to try it out.  

There is not too much to say about the ambience or service.  It is your typical vietnamese pho shop.  I ordered their special rice plate cause I didn't really want soup for dinner.  The flavor was okay, but I was disappointed by the portion size.  I think the plate it self was north of $10 and although there was variety in the combo plate, there was little of actual quantity.  I guess I'm just used to getting mounds of the same food for the same price or even less at other Vietnamese places.  

The food is okay, but with all the other options in the neighborhood, I doubt I would come back here.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Got Bun Bo Hue and it was not good. It was literally pho broth with chili oil in it. The only things they changed were the noodles and meats to go along with it. Seriously, if you're going to offer bun bo hue, at least make it right. The broth I had contained zero fish sauce, shrimp paste or lemon grass. Instead,  It was just star anise and cinammon, both of which are NOT found in bun bo hue. Google the recipe and you'll see that I'm right. For $10 this was the biggest rip off ever. Half way through I just gave up and got me a banh mi next door instead.

I should have known though, the staff are clearly viet/chinese. There were maybe 3 other asian people in the restaurant. Most people got rice dishes or dry bun.

My advice is to NOT come here frankly and go to one of the other pho spots instead.
author: edward k.

description: This place was great. Food is healthy and clean. My favorite was papaya salad and smoothies. They were so good.  But one thing i did not like was waiter. She was so  slow and didn't come to our table util we went ask for come.
author: Irene J.

description:
I have visited them on numerous occasions and enjoy their food. Recently however I think it is true that they are going overboard with the MSG and I am not even one of those picky neurotic Cali Phonies. 

Ordered some pho and spring rolls to go. Everything was fresh and tasty. I like that the meat they use for the pho is marbled it was very good.

Unfortunately after eating my tongue had a weird tingling going and again I am not your typical picky San Francisco food neurotic. 

Hours and hours later my tongue still had that weird thing going on. 

I eat Vietnamese food approximately four times a week and that was a first for me.

If someone from the restaurant is reading this you guys do not need to go that heavy on the MSG. Your food is good and the ingredients are fresh lighten up thank you
author: SF T.

description:
Had some pho in the morning after a night out. It wasn't the best pho, but my standards were pretty low at that moment, so whatevs. Def probably better elsewhere. They also used a wider noodle, as opposed to thin one that I'm used to always getting in my pho tai. I don't know if you can request it, but FYI default noodles are not the normals! 

Most of my friends felt the same about this place, less the one that suggested it. I think it's his favorite??
author: Kathleen C.

description:
******************************* 975 *******************************

   Kind of loving this place, former spot of that mean owner of Turtle Tower resto, much nicer folks here now. 

   They serve good 

- PHO GA - chicken noodle soup, and with beansprout and herbs.

- Banh Uot -  a Vietnamese thin pancake wrapper consisting of rice noodle sheets, eaten with NUOC CHAM (mixed fish sauce), fried shallots, and a side of ch la (Vietnamese pork sausage). 

- Bun Bo Hue - spicy beef noodle soup, not bad at all for San Francisco.

     CHEAP eats, quality food, good service, 1 of my GO-TO for Vietnamese lunch fix in the Tenderloin. 


P.S. You can park your car at the hotel across the street for $3.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: The ingredients in the pho were tasty, credited by the 2 starts. However, the broth had absolutely no flavor. It tasted like slightly fatty water. The restaurant was clean and the staff friendly. For a Vietnamese restaurant in a Vietnamese neighborhood the pho was surprisingly bland.
author: Jorel J.

description: I come here often for lunch during work. I usually always go for #22 combination beef pho. They uses a different kind of noodle here. It is not the small thin noodles you get at pho shops. Their noodle are thick and soft! Their meat is very different from other pho restaurant I been too.I love the meat they put in the noodles. It is very tender and soft.
author: Louise C.

description:
Some say even Michael Jordan has off nights but Golden Lotus has yet to fail me.

#3 is one of the most damn delicious things in San Francisco. 

#29 (ask for very spicy) is a party in the mouth. 

People and environment are superior to Turle Tower.  The one downside is that there are zombies outside
author: Beef S.

description: Incredible fresh rolls in pork and tofu varieties. Ordered 30 rolls for pick up at the last minute for an event and the staff kindly obliged! Such kind people and incredible fresh food. Wish we ordered 90 of the rice paper rolls!
author: Phoebe D.

description:
Got Pho (vegetarian and beef) and a rice dish. 

Service was very friendly and prompt and the ingredients tasted fairly fresh.

Why the one star review?

All four people in my party got really severe headaches later from the gratuitous amount of MSG included in every dish. I would recommend avoiding this place, especially if you are sensitive to MSG or easily get headaches.
author: Alex M.

description: I'd go back here just for their service. They were unbelievably generous and attentive. Doesn't happen very often for Asian restaurants- I know this, I'm Asian. Pho was delicious and the portions were large.
author: Yunah R.

description:
Go here instead of Turtle Tower. My friends and I went to Turtle tower but after seeing how long the line was we decided to go to Golden Lotus. There's no wait and their chicken pho is delicious. I am usually not a pho person...but I tried their chicken pho and it was really good. 

I like that their noodles are wider than the usual noodles that you see in pho. It's hard to describe but the texture of their noodles make it seem that their noodles are freshly made (I'm not sure if they actually are).
author: Theresa L.

description:
After a crazy weekend all we wanted to do was put on pjs and watch football on the couch with some pho. After searching yelp we stumbled upon this place and decided to try it out & get take out... And I'm so mad right now.

We both got chicken pho and the noodles are mushy, the chicken is weird parts and the broth is super salty and looks like there's oil in it. Neither of us could even finish half because there was just too much salt. 

We also ordered the fresh spring rolls with no mint and instead we got crispy egg rolls that are just ok.

Such a fail and waste of 25$. I wish we woulda paid with a card instead of cash so we could request money back for their mix up. 

Needless to say, we won't be returning.
author: danielle a.

description: I've been going to this place for over a year now. They've yet to disappoint me. Absolutely love their beef stew noodle and their hospitality. Despite it being in the tenderloin, the area is really not too sketchy; the interior's comfortable and nostalgic even. The price range is pretty standard given it's in the city, but the portion is good to get you a little over past the full stomach bar.
author: Mabel T.

description: This is a nice mom and pop like restaurant that has decent pho and great appetizers. For starters try out number three which is their spring roles with their marinated meet but what is different is trey use s nice thick noodle.  The spiced pho Chicken broth is yummy and filling and number 63 is done tasty fish. Definitely one of the best pho stops in sf
author: Robert H.

description:
I came here with some co-workers for lunch and they were able to accommodate the 7 of us in their back dining room. They were great at bringing waters and teas for everyone and took everyone's orders promptly. 

However, there were a few things that went wrong during our dining experience. 

1. Firstly, we all ordered at the same time. Half of us ordered dry vermicelli and rice dishes and the other half ordered pho soup noodles. One of our coworkers got his order of pho noodles within the first 5 minutes of ordering, but the rest of us got our food at least 10 minutes afterwards. Which was strange...because you would think that the pho noodles would all come out first around the same time, but it was very sporadic. My co-worker that got his food first said his soup came out lukewarm too. So it left us all wondering whether or not he got a messed up order from a different party... 

2. Another friend from my group ordered the 5 spice chicken pho. However, when she got her chicken all her chicken pieces were pink on the inside (like abnormally pink) AND she said it did not taste like chicken. Some of us were wondering if it was duck.. It was bad enough that they served her under cooked chicken but it would be even worse if they had served here some mystery meat that wasn't chicken. Perhaps the chicken had freezer burn and therefore was extremely pink? She told the waitress and the waitress apologized and brought it in for the kitchen to re-cook. When the order of chicken was re-done, most of the chicken was cooked this time, except a few end pieces were STILL pink. She pointed it out to the waitress again because she wanted the kitchen know they kept giving her pink chicken. To have to send uncooked meat back to the kitchen twice is pretty terrible. Again, I am unsure as to why the chicken was that color (it was dark pink- close to red in color) but they should not have been serving it. I think they should have taken it off the bill but they never offered. 

With those two things in mind, I ordered the dry vermicelli noodles with vegetables (egg, shiitake mushrooms and sprouts) and vegetarian imperial rolls. The overall dish was alright. Not the best. The noodles tasted like they were frozen and not heated back up all the way since they were slightly hard and not chewy. The Imperial rolls were good. 

I personally would not choose to come back here. You have plenty of other good/decent Vietnamese restaurants in the area to choose from. I would be cautious ordering their chicken!
author: Sam L.

description: My new favorite Pho ga place thanks to my co-worker's recommendation. Love the rice rolls with grilled lemongrass pork and generous side order of stir fry baby bok choy. The hubby recommends the special beef combo pho.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Was in the neighborhood for some pho and bun when we noticed a Grand Opening sign at the former location of Turtle Tower and decided to check it out. 

Entering the restaurant, the restaurant was clean and well lit.  We were seated in the front room, which had about 10 tables.  The menu consists of appetizers, pho, bun, garlic noodle dishes, rice plates, and vegetarian items.  

We ordered:
- Pho Dac Biet Pho Noodle Soup - consists of rib eye steak, tripe, well-done flank steak, tendon and beef meatballs (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-lotus-san-francisco?select=S_J1Y_bziS8A_NzMB7uSpw#dFkWM9Z_IKswokoO4Ce_1Q) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-lotus-san-francisco?select=S_J1Y_bziS8A_NzMB7uSpw#XVHMWJG3Ews2_7_WT2As4A).  With a choice of small ($7.15) or large ($8.15), I opted for a large bowl with the rib eye steak on the side so that I can place it in the soup on my own.  They don't use the typical rice noodles, but a slightly wider rice noodle.  The broth had good flavor, but it was not piping hot.  Also, the bowl was not comparable to the "large" size served by the establishment a couple storefronts down.  I would consider it "medium" in size.

- Bun Thit Nuong Cha Gio - consists of grilled pork and imperial rolls over noodles, lettuce, bean sprouts and peanuts. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-lotus-san-francisco?select=S_J1Y_bziS8A_NzMB7uSpw#CyJiPWg1yc61MQcUbaAlYQ)Good sized bowl at a reasonable price of $6.65.  

There was always a steady stream of customers coming in while we were there.  Not sure, if it was due to it being a new restaurant or people wandering in thinking it was still the Turtle Tower, which had moved two storefronts away.

Overall, service from the waitresses and the servers were friendly.  Food was good, but the value was in the bun dishes.  The pho soups were on the pricier side relative to the size of the bowls.
author: Al L.

description:
i would be embarrassed if my vietnamese parents made ca kho the way this restaurant does, and for $10.25, it was a rip off. the sauce was neither flavorful nor the right consistency, like a very americanized version of claypot fish. even i can do better. pretty disappointed since i was hoping this would be a legit vietnamese spot. 

they also charged me the wrong price for the ca kho, but apologized. also charged me the wrong price for a side order of white rice.
author: Ai N.

description: Had the bun bo hue and the lemongrass pork roll. The flavor of the bun bo hue was good but the soup was lukewarm. Definitely better bun bo hue places in the tenderloin. The pork roll was simple and delicious, but not enough to warrant a 4 or 5 star for the restaurant.
author: Derrick W.

description:
This place is a gem nestled in a super seedy area in the T-Loin.  Their combination pho has a ton of different stuff in it (rare beef steak, flank, tendon, tripe, beef ball) and the broth is really flavorful and rich.  They provide sprouts, lime, jalapenos, and basil on the side, but if you like something else with your pho (cilantro, etc) they are happy to oblige.  Their imperial rolls and other rolls are also very good.

The interior is very clean and bright, and our food came out really fast.  They take credit cards, too, which is unusual in Viet mom-and-pop shops.  

If you can get past the used needles and human waste on the ground on Larkin, you will be glad you made the trip.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Golden Lotus is a no-frills hole in the wall Vietnamese noodle shop that is packed to the gills with MSG-laden flavor.  Seriously, the sodium content in their broth left our hero's tongue feeling pickled until the next morning.  The service is fast and speaks English well, and their clientele is fairly diverse.  A lot of single diners seem to come here for a basic cheap meal and they really do deliver on value here.  One odd part about their pho is that they use flat rice noodles in the pho instead of traditional noodles.

PROS:
- Cheap prices.
- Variety of noodle and rice dishes available.
- The "small" size servings are enormous and more than ample for a meal.

CONS:
- $10 minimum for credit cards.
- MSG overload in the broth.
- Pho is light on the meat.
author: Albert W.

description: In its former incarnation as Turtle Tower this was one of my favorite spots in the universe, but I suppose all good things must come to an end, and the glory of Turtle Tower, or more specificity the rich broth and perfect noodles of its chicken pho, were no exception. Golden Lotus is probably the equivalent of any other decent bowl of pho in the city, but pales in comparison to its great predecessor. Rest in power Turtle Tower, rest in power.
author: Albert P.

description:
When Turtle Tower shifted to the right two spaces, it left a void for Golden Lotus. I suppose it really would be bizarre if anything but a pho joint sprouted up here.

Still serving northern-style pho, so the rice noodles are on the thicker side. Broth doesn't have the same oomph that you expect from good long hours of stewing though. Tasty enough, though the pho was overshadowed by the appetizer bunh cuon we had.

Might give it another stab soon.
author: Kevin L.

description: I had the pho and it was disappointing. Although the broth was very good, the meat (I ordered beef), was all fat and then noodles were thick spaghetti noodles, not the clear rice noodles that pho is usually made with. The pricing is also pretty high, in consideration that it's pho you're getting. Maybe they have other food that is better but I would never get their pho again.
author: Jannet H.

description: The soup (pho) is terrible that I ever have. My Starbucks Coffee is hotter than their soup. Lots of MSG and little bit meats. I ordered combination meat soup, the small size $9, that is ridiculous. Won't go back again! The worst soup in the city.
author: robert l.

description:
I had high hopes for this restaurant, as they are open late and open on Tuesdays. I ordered the Pho Tai and the Banh Xeo for take out the other day. 

The Pho Tai, was flavorless. I had to add in my own beef stock powder and salt to make it more flavorful. The broth was bland and didnt have the rich flavor that one would expect from pho. Additionally, the noodles were the wider flat rice noodle variety. It would have been fine had the texture been okay, but the noodles were soft and would break creating a soup full of noodle fragments. 

 The Banh Xeo, vietnamese pancake, was drenched in grease. It was placed on top of a paper towel that was completely soaked with oil. Yet, the pancake was still too greasy and heavy. 

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to other, at least for take out. Tenderloin is full of other vietnamese restaurants, go for one of those.
author: Andy C.

description:
Looking at the pictures for Golden Lotus brings back fond memories of my meal there. For SF, Golden Lotus offers solid and affordable Vietnamese food. Disclaimer - I come from the land of cheap Vietnamese eats (San Gabriel Valley in LA) so  my standards are somewhat unrealistic and overly harsh.

My boyfriend and I ordered the bi cuon (shredded pork rolls) to share. The shredded pork was reminiscent of my childhood and oh-so-yummy, and paired so well with the fresh crispiness of the mints. The flavor of the rolls was amazing. The size of the rolls were applause-worthy too. No sad, limp rolls here. There are 2 to an order, but they halve the rolls and it's definitely enough to be 4 rolls.

I ordered the pho with rare beef and beef balls. I love beef balls (heehee). For those who don't, you can order rare beef with other options - tripe, tendon, and if you don't like those either, you can go with just straight up beef. I appreciated that they were not stingy with the beef and beef balls. One strange thing I did notice was that although you could choose the type of noodle you want, by default they used thick rice noodles which are not traditionally in pho. The pho is better off, imo, with thin rice noodles as the default and customers should be able to switch to another noodle type if they wish.

My boyfriend had the beef stew (bo kho). The dish was definitely hearty (as it should be). It had plenty of beef (including tendon which not everyone will like, he certainly didn't), carrots, and a small amount of noodles. Value!! The only complaint here was that the stew was very oily, more oily than I think it should have been. I think the stew needs to be "leaner", but the flavor was awesome.

I meant for this to be a short review but my unyielding passion for Vietnamese food got the better of me. Hopefully this review was helpful, got your taste buds going, and you'll give Golden Lotus a try!
author: Brandy A.

description:
This place replaced the turtle tower restaurant so I wanted to see if this place was comparable to its last owner. But seeing how the workers were all new it was just wishful expectations. The menu had similar food selection though. 

My choice: bun xao sa (aka vermicelli noodles w/ lemongrass beef)
Lemongrass is an ingredient that you can't really go wrong with so its always my go to choice if a restaurant offers it. This comes either with chicken, beef, or tofu (might not be tofu but there was a vegan option). First of all the noodle portion was pretty minimal and so I noticed they tried to compensate for the bowl space by filling it with cabbage and other veggies. Very sneaky of them -_- I wouldn't mind the lack of noodles, however, because it was good portion control but I felt like more noodles would've been necessary considering how salty they made the beef. On top of adding the fish sauce, I felt like I was eating a bowl of salt. Although it gave the dish pretty good flavoring, I don't like to have a meal where it consist of me drinking water 80% of the time. I would not order this again unless I'm in a water drinking mood. 

Service: 
I went when it was fairly empty (only had 3 other customers) and despite the lack of customers the service was pretty slow. I went next door to Lee's sandwich to get myself a drink, spent a good 15 mins in there, came back to the restaurant and had to wait another good 10 mins before my food came.
author: Annie V.

description: Owner is nice and always has a smile on his face. One of a good Vietnamese restaurant in that area. My favorite is Spicy Beef Noodle and Tomato Crab Meat soup. The food came out fast. If you are in a hurry and looking for a fast decent Vietnamese food, yes, this is it.
author: Queenie L.

description: Surprised this place didn't have more reviews. Pho Tai for me. The small size was HUGE, only ate half. Broth was rich. Noodles were the big flat kind which was a fun surprise. Meat was tender and sides were fresh. My new favorite pho place (for now)
author: Kaila L.

description:
My go-to Tenderloin pho joint is Pho 2000 next door, but on one particular weekend when went to get my pho fix, I had to opt for Golden Lotus because the owners of Pho 2000 were on vacation.  While I had high hopes that this neighboring restaurant would have equally as good (if not better) pho, I was unimpressed.

First of all, I ordered a very standard pho noodle soup with beef broth, brisket and flank steak. This, in my opinion, is a very typical order that they must get pretty often, but our waiter failed to mention that here, pho noodles means flat wide rice noodles equivalent to Chinese 'fun' noodles.  When my order came out, I was expecting the thin angel hair thick noodle that I was used to, and when I made a comment to the waiter, he said that this is their version of pho, and if I wanted to order the other kind of noodle, I would have had to request it as an alternative. I thought this noodle was very bland and lacked the texture and chewiness that other pho noodles have, and these wide noodles kind of just fell apart mushily even when I was just scooping it out of the broth.
